channel.title: Hello on PEP Class 2020
channel.description: Recent content in Hello on PEP Class 2020

item.title: Measuring the ocean
item.description: How we measure Temperature and Salinity The basic tool for measuring the temperature and salinity of the ocean is the CTD (Conductivity-Temperature-Depth) device which we lower from the side of a ship to record a vertical trace (or profile) of the ocean. The following video came from a cruise in the North Atlantic in 2012.

item.title: Measuring the ocean
item.description: How we measure Temperature and Salinity The basic tool for measuring the temperature and salinity of the ocean is the CTD (Conductivity-Temperature-Depth) device which we lower from the side of a ship to record a vertical trace (or profile) of the ocean. The following video came from a cruise in the North Atlantic in 2012.

item.title: Carbon and Oxygen
item.description: Chemical Oceanography is concerned with the the study of the interaction of dissolved ions, molecules, gasses in the ocean. This is a diverse field and we will be covering the basics of macronutrients, oxygen and carbon in this class. This will be a necessarily broad overview. Reading Read the following from Segar: Chapter 5: The Dissolving Power of Water (pg. 94-95) Sources and Sinks of Chemicals Dissolved in Seawater (pg.

item.title: Data descovery and initial plotting
item.description: Reading You should read Sections 3.1 to 3.6 (and skim the rest) of Chapter 3 of R for Data Science by Garrett Grolemund and Hadley Wickham. This should introduced you to the basic ideas behind ggplot and helped you create your first plots using their built-in data. ggplot is a powerful tool for producing elegant graphics and is relatively simple to use once you’ve mastered a few key ideas.

item.title: Phytoplankton and Nutrients
item.description: Reading Watch this accessible intro to phytoplankton Read the following from Segar: Chapter 12: only pg 285 - 296. Critical Concept 14, which covers light, nutrients and photosynthesis in the ocean. Listen to this podcast about putting excess nitrogen into a local watershed: SEA Semester · Fixing Nitrogen Exercises Submit a Google Doc with your answers to these questions to Google Classroom.

item.title: Temperature, Salinity and Density
item.description: Physical Oceanography is the study of how water moves. This includes ocean currents, waves and large scale ocean circulation. Some of the most fundamental ideas revolve around the key physical properties of the water: Temperature, Salinity and Density. We will explore these properties and how they allow or limit movement of water in the ocean. Reading Read the following from Segar: Chapter 1: Introduction (pg. 1-2) The Oceans and Earth’s Environment (pg.

item.title: Getting Started in R
item.description: Our goal in learning R is to introduce you to some skills in exploring oceanographic data in R. This will mainly involve plotting tools, but will also include some discussion of working with data sets. NOTE: There is no exercise submission or Peer Discussion requirements for this work, but please reach out on the course Slack channel if you have any technical issues. Why R? Perhaps the best place to start is to ask ourselves why we are choosing to use R.

item.title: Getting Started in R
item.description: Our goal in learning R is to introduce you to some skills in exploring oceanographic data in R. This will mainly involve plotting tools, but will also include some discussion of working with data sets. NOTE: There is no exercise submission or Peer Discussion requirements for this work, but please reach out on the course Slack channel if you have any technical issues. Why R? Perhaps the best place to start is to ask ourselves why we are choosing to use R.

item.title: Introduction
item.description: Course Goals During the course we have two main goals: Develop student understanding of topics in ocean and environmental science pertinent to global climate change with a focus on activities in the Woods Hole science community. Build student research skills to aid their summer internship work and future careers. The first goal will be achieved through a series of classes on basic oceanography spanning physics, chemistry and biology. These classes will be supplemented with more advanced topics, introduced by leading researchers in the Woods Hole community, that will bring students’ understanding to the frontier of current understanding.

item.title: R Resources
item.description: Learning any programming language can be both completely frustrating and hugely rewarding. Be kind to yourself and try to see past the struggles to the glorious highs that will come. We’ll be doing some intro work in the course, mostly centered around data visualization, but here is a selection of other resources that you might find useful in exploring the field further. R for Data Science by Garrett Grolemund and Hadley Wickham: Core text on exploring data in R.

item.title: Schedule
item.description: Daily Routine For most days of the class, the scheduled routine will be in EDT (PDT): 1200 (0900): Deadline for submission of exercise responses 1200-1300 (0900-1000): 30 min Peer Discussions 1300-1400 (0900-1100): Slack Comments 1400-1500 (1100-1200: Class Time Ahead of the peer discussion, you will need to have read the days content and submitted something as a response to the exercises posted. East coast students will probably be able to accomplish the reading and exercises the morning of the class, West coast students will probably have to do this work the previous evening.
